summary: This is a sealed motion filed by the United States in the case of Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 vs. United States, seeking dismissal of the petitioners' Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) petition for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The government argues the petitioners lack standing and their claims are not constitutionally ripe, primarily because invalidating the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein would not redress their alleged injury and they retain the ability to confer with prosecutors. This is a sealed motion filed by the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, seeking to dismiss the claims of two Jane Doe petitioners for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The motion argues that the petitioners' claims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) regarding the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein are not ripe, as they have not been denied the opportunity to confer with prosecutors about potential future charges in other districts.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida. He pleaded guilty to state charges and served an 18-month sentence as part of the agreement.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking to enforce rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, alleging denial of consultation regarding the disposition of charges against Epstein.

persons.name: Jane Doe #2
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking to enforce rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act. Declined an invitation to meet with the United States Attorney.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who authorized the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Villafafia
persons.context: An AUSA from the USAO-SDFL who spoke to the petitioners about the offenses committed against them by Epstein prior to the signing of the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Wilfredo A. Ferrer
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who respectfully submitted the motion to dismiss on behalf of the government.

persons.name: Dexter A. Lee
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney in Miami who is listed as an attorney for the respondent (the United States) on the motion.

persons.name: Eduardo I. Sanchez
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney in Miami who is listed as an attorney for the respondent (the United States) on the motion.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafana
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney in West Palm Beach who is listed as an attorney for the respondent (the United States) on the motion.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, listed on the service list for the case.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, listed on the service list for the case.

persons.name: Donald M. Middlebrooks
persons.context: The judge who signed the sealed order granting the government's motion for limited disclosure of grand jury matter.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, authorized the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution.
Jane Doe #1 is a petitioner alleging Epstein committed federal sex offenses against her as a minor.
Jane Doe #2 is a petitioner alleging Epstein committed federal sex offenses against her as a minor.
AUSA Villafafia spoke to Jane Doe #1 about the offenses committed against her by Epstein prior to the non-prosecution agreement.
Edwards is listed as an attorney for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2.
Cassell is listed as an attorney for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2.
Ferrer is the U.S. Attorney and Lee is an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the same office, both representing the government.

events.title: Hearing on CVRA Petition
events.description: A court hearing where petitioners acknowledged the non-prosecution agreement induced Epstein's guilty plea and sought its invalidation to confer with prosecutors.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney
events.description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida personally conferred with petitioners' counsel and Jane Doe #1 about their desire to see Epstein federally prosecuted.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea and Incarceration
events.description: As induced by the non-prosecution agreement, Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state criminal charges and served an 18-month sentence of state incarceration.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Execution
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (USAO-SDFL) entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, which is the central subject of the petitioners' claims.

events.title: CVRA Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 filed a petition under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) challenging the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein (Case No. 08-80736-Civ-Marra).

events.title: Government Files Motion to Dismiss
events.description: The United States filed this sealed motion to dismiss the petitioners' CVRA claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, arguing the claims are not ripe.

events.title: Court Orders Limited Grand Jury Disclosure
events.description: Judge Donald M. Middlebrooks issued a sealed order granting the government's motion for limited disclosure of grand jury matter to the petitioners' attorneys in the related CVRA case.

keyFacts: The U.S. government argues the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over the CVRA petition because the petitioners (Jane Doe #1 and #2) lack Article III standing and their claims are not constitutionally ripe.
The primary relief sought by petitioners is to invalidate the non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

The government contends that even if the non-prosecution agreement were set aside, due process would require the U.S. to adhere to its terms because Epstein has already performed his obligations (pleading guilty and serving state time).
The document reveals that the USAO-SDFL has been recused from the Epstein matter, with responsibility reassigned to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Middle District of Florida.

The non-prosecution agreement only bars prosecution in the Southern District of Florida; Epstein remains subject to potential federal prosecution in other districts like the Southern District of New York and District of New Jersey.

The 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein did not bar the United States from bringing federal criminal charges against him in any other district besides the Southern District of Florida for the offenses covered by the NPA.

The U.S. Attorney's Manual required express written approval from other districts or the Criminal Division to make an agreement that binds another district, which the USAO-SDFL did not have for the Epstein NPA.

The government argues the petitioners' CVRA claims are not ripe because they have not been denied the opportunity to confer with prosecutors in districts (like SDNY or New Jersey) that could still potentially charge Epstein.

A sealed court order from November 7, 2011, authorized limited disclosure of grand jury information from two federal grand juries (05-02 and 07-103) to the attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 for use in their CVRA lawsuit.
